sub_subject.name: Scientific Inquiry, Method & Worldview
sub_subject.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Scientific Inquiry, Method & Worldview (Science & Nature)

objectives.objective_text: Name numbers found in a test.
Identify a chart.
Identify outliers.
Identify a silly reason.
Name "Because I said so".
Identify Circular Reasoning.
Identify asking a friend to check work.
Name working together.
Identify a scientific journal.
Identify asking a question and testing it.
Name "Science" as studying the world.
Identify limits of observation (can't observe history directly).
Identify that we should use tools for good.
Name helping people as a goal.
Identify dangerous inventions (weapons).
Identify that a watch needs a watchmaker.
Name God as the Designer.
Identify Irreducible Complexity (mousetrap analogy).
Identify that nature shows God's power.
Name "Wow!" as a prayer.
Identify Johannes Kepler ("Thinking God's thoughts after Him").
Identify that many scientists loved God.
Name Isaac Newton.
Identify Galileo and the Church (complex relationship).
Identify why results might be different.
Identify outliers (results that don't fit).
Identify what we will change and what we will keep the same.
Identify the Independent Variable (what I change) and Dependent Variable (what I measure).
Identify what I see with my eyes (Observation).
Name a guess about what happened (Inference).
Identify measuring carefully.
Name the right number.
Identify human error (reading the ruler wrong).
Identify a magnifying glass.
Name a microscope as a tool for tiny things.
Identify safety goggles.
Name 'Don't touch without asking'.
Identify the fire extinguisher.
Identify a ruler (inches/centimeters).
Name a scale for weighing.
Recall that we must tell the truth about what happened.
Observe that people can make mistakes.
Recall that just because two things happen together doesn't mean one caused the other.
Observe jumping to conclusions.
Recall that scientists check each other.
Observe that sometimes scientists disagree.
Recall that science can't answer "Why are we here?".
Observe that science studies things we can see/touch.
Recall that just because we can do something doesn't mean we should.
Observe doctors caring for life.
Recall that accidents don't make complex machines.
Observe the complexity of an eye or wing.
Recall Psalm 19 ("The heavens declare...").
Observe beauty in a microscope.
Recall that the church built universities.
Observe that faith helps us understand the world.
Listen to what my friends found.
Recall that scientists are curious.
List the materials needed for an experiment.
Recall that we need to look closely.
Recall that we check our work.
Recall that there are things too small to see with eyes.
Observe a bug or leaf up close.
Recall that we wash hands after science.
Observe rules to stay safe.
Recall that we measure to be exact.
Observe that liquids are measured in cups or liters.
Plan a simple test (e.g., which ball bounces higher).
Summarize why we repeat experiments.
Explain "Bias" (wanting a certain answer).
Explain "Cherry Picking" data.
Defend the necessity of honesty in reporting.
Summarize Post Hoc (After this, therefore because of this).
Explain Ad Hominem (attacking the scientist, not the science).
Explain the Naturalistic Fallacy (Natural = Good).
Defend logical rigor as a tool for truth.
Summarize the Peer Review process.
Explain why "Consensus" (everyone agrees) isn't always proof.
Explain the role of skepticism.
Defend the self-correcting nature of the scientific method.
Summarize the Scientific Method (Hypothesis, Test, Conclusion).
Explain "Scientism" (thinking science is the only way to know truth).
Explain epistemological humility.
Defend other ways of knowing (logic, revelation, history).
Summarize the Golden Rule in science.
Explain the sanctity of life.
Defend the moral boundaries of experimentation.
Summarize the Design Argument (Teleology).
Explain "Naturalism" (nature is all there is).
Explain the failure of random mutation to create new information.
Defend the scientific validity of detecting design.
Summarize that studying the world honors the Maker.
Explain that truth is God's truth.
Explain the mandate to subdue the earth as worship.
Defend the compatibility of faith and reason.
Summarize the Christian roots of modern science.
Explain why science grew in Christian Europe (belief in order).
Explain the Royal Society's motto ("Nullius in verba" - take nobody's word).
Defend the thesis that Christianity birthed science.
Decide if my guess was right.
Tell others what I found.
Ask 'Did we get the same answer?'
Summarize what the data tells us.
Explain if the hypothesis was supported or rejected.
Explain the importance of Peer Review (scientists checking each other).
Defend a conclusion using statistical evidence.
Ask 'Why?' about things in nature.
Wonder what will happen if we change something.
Choose a question we can answer by looking or testing.
Formulate a question that can be tested (Testable Question).
Distinguish between a question about facts vs. opinions.
Predict the answer (Hypothesis) using 'I think... because...'.
Explain why we need to ask clear questions.
Defend the necessity of operational definitions in research questions.
Count things and use tally marks.
Draw a picture of the result.
Sort items into groups.
Measure with a ruler or cup.
Use a bar graph to show results.
Take accurate measurements using standard units.
Label drawings with scientific names.
Defend the integrity of data handling (no cherry-picking).
Follow a recipe or list of steps.
Use safe hands when testing.
Explain why we need a 'Fair Test' (Controls).
Write a step-by-step procedure.
Explain how to minimize human error.
Defend the reproducibility of the method.
Describe an object using color, shape, and size.
Summarize the difference: Observation is a fact, Inference is an explanation.
Explain that 'The ground is wet' is an observation, 'It rained' is an inference.
Record observations accurately without guessing.
Explain the danger of bias in observation.
Defend the objectivity of data collection.
Try again if we mess up.
Summarize the difference between estimating and measuring.
Explain why we measure three times (trials).
Explain systematic vs. random error.
Defend the appropriate number of significant figures in a calculation.
Summarize how to hold a microscope (arm and base).
Explain what a slide is.
Draw what is seen in the eyepiece.
Explain how to prepare a wet mount slide.
Defend the proper use of coarse vs. fine adjustment.
Summarize the rules for a lab (no running, no eating).
Explain why we wear goggles (protect eyes).
Explain how to handle broken glass.
Defend the zero-tolerance policy for horseplay in the lab.
Summarize the main metric units: Meter (length), Liter (volume), Gram (mass).
Explain the prefixes: Kilo- (1000), Centi- (1/100), Milli- (1/1000).
Convert meters to centimeters.
Explain why science uses SI units globally.
Defend the importance of standardization in science.
Compare qualitative data (words) with quantitative data (numbers).
Compare a fair test with an unfair test.
Analyze correlation vs. causation.
Interpret error bars and uncertainty.
Connect funding sources to potential bias.
Compare an argument from authority vs. evidence.
Analyze the Straw Man argument in scientific debates.
Interpret the Equivocation fallacy (changing definitions).
Connect the "God of the Gaps" fallacy.
Compare a blog post with a study.
Analyze the reproducibility crisis.
Interpret the history of paradigm shifts (Kuhn).
Connect groupthink to scientific stagnation.
Compare a scientific question with a moral question.
Interpret the difference between operational and historical science.
Connect assumptions (uniformitarianism) to conclusions.
Compare healing vs. enhancing humans.
Analyze CRISPR and genetic editing ethics.
Interpret the role of AI (Artificial Intelligence).
Connect the Image of God to bioethics.
Explain stewardship of the environment.
Compare a robot with a human.
Analyze the information content of DNA.
Interpret the "Fine Tuning" of the universe constants.
Connect Specified Complexity to intelligence.
Compare curiosity with worship.
Analyze the motivation of early Christian scientists.
Interpret scientific discovery as revelation of God's character (order/beauty).
Connect awe to humility.
Compare magic (unpredictable) with science (laws).
Analyze the myth of the "Dark Ages".
Interpret the role of monks in preserving knowledge.
Connect the Reformation to the scientific revolution.
Compare my results with another group's results.
Analyze the sources of error in the experiment.
Interpret the relationship between variables (direct/inverse).
Connect the conclusion back to the original question.
Analyze a problem to identify the variables involved.
Connect the research question to existing knowledge.
Analyze data for patterns and trends.
Calculate the mean, median, and mode of results.
Analyze an experimental design for flaws or bias.
Interpret the role of a Control Group vs. Experimental Group.
Connect sample size to the reliability of the test.
Analyze how prior knowledge influences inference.
Interpret data points without jumping to conclusions.
Connect observation to the concept of empirical evidence.
Compare 'Close enough' with 'Exact'.
Analyze the difference between Accuracy (correctness) and Precision (repeatability).
Interpret the meniscus when measuring liquid volume.
Connect significant figures to the precision of the tool.
Compare Low Power vs. High Power magnification.
Analyze the parts: Eyepiece, Objective Lens, Stage, Focus knobs.
Interpret the image orientation (inverted).
Calculate total magnification (Eyepiece x Objective).
Compare safe behavior with dangerous behavior.
Analyze the MSDS (Material Safety Data Sheet) symbols.
Interpret the proper way to smell chemicals (wafting).
Connect safety gear (gloves, apron) to specific hazards.
Compare the Metric system (base 10) with the Imperial system.
Analyze the relationship between volume and mass (1ml of water = 1g).
Interpret dimensional analysis for unit conversion.
Connect Kelvin to Celsius.
Evaluate sample size and selection.
Evaluate the "No True Scotsman" fallacy in taxonomy.
Evaluate the "Appeal to Majority" fallacy in science.
Evaluate the statement "Science says...".
Evaluate the "Play God" objection.
Evaluate the "Blind Watchmaker" thesis.
Evaluate the conflict thesis (science vs. religion) as false history.
Evaluate the Scopes Trial narrative.
Evaluate the validity of a scientific claim based on methodology.
Critique a question that is too vague to be tested.
Evaluate the falsifiability of a hypothesis (Popper).
Evaluate the statistical significance of data (Standard Deviation).
Evaluate the ethics of an experimental design.
Evaluate historical science (inference-heavy) vs. operational science (observation-heavy).
Evaluate the % Error of a result.
Evaluate the resolution limits of light microscopes vs. electron microscopes.
Evaluate the protocol for chemical spills (acid vs. base).
Evaluate the precision of different measuring instruments.
Create a data table to record numbers.
Construct a critique of a scientific paper's methodology.
Synthesize statistical literacy with scientific literacy.
Construct a logical breakdown of a pseudoscience claim.
Construct a review of a peer-reviewed article.
Synthesize sociology of science.
Construct a demarcation of science vs. non-science.
Synthesize the integration of faith and science.
Construct a Christian response to transhumanism.
Synthesize technological progress with moral regression.
Construct a defense of Design based on probability.
Construct a prayer based on scientific facts.
Synthesize the study of creation with the adoration of the Creator.
Construct a biography of a faithful scientist (Pascal, Boyle, Faraday).
Synthesize historical context with scientific development.
Construct a formal lab report (Abstract, Method, Data, Conclusion).
Synthesize the collaborative nature of the scientific community.
Construct a Null Hypothesis (no change) and an Alternative Hypothesis.
Construct a complex research proposal based on a gap in literature.
Synthesize multiple observations to form a novel hypothesis.
Construct line graphs for continuous data.
Construct a scatter plot with a line of best fit.
Synthesize error bars and uncertainty in data presentation.
Construct a double-blind experiment protocol (if applicable).
Synthesize multiple variables using multivariate analysis concepts.
Construct an argument separating raw data from theoretical interpretation.
Synthesize observations to support or reject a theory.
Construct an error analysis for a lab experiment.
Synthesize the concept of uncertainty in all measurement.
Construct a diagram of cell structures viewed under high power.
Synthesize staining techniques to identify cell parts.
Construct a risk assessment for a specific reaction.
Synthesize the ethical disposal of chemical waste.
Construct complex unit conversions (e.g., g/cm to kg/m).
Synthesize derived units (Newtons, Joules) from base units.
Analyze the domain of science vs. philosophy/theology.
Synthesize information theory with biology.
Synthesize philosophy of science with logic.
